fields: What is an infant industry?

An infant inustry is a relatively new industry in an economy that has not had the opportunity to benefit from economies of scale. It is one of the main arguments against trade-liberalisation, as a country could have a comparative advantage in producing a good/service, but due to the industry being very new, it has not had the time to specialise in said good's production.
What is the Infant industry argument supporting trade protection?

1. Infant Industry argument: Infant industries are relatively new industries that have not had the time to fully establish themselves and start benefiting from economies of scale. Thus, local firms under free-trade will find it difficult to compete with more established, mature firms that have comparatively lower average costs of production. This argument rests on the idea that the country may have a comparative advantage in producing this good but are unable to do so because it has not had the time to fully specialise in producing said good.
What is the national security argument supporting trade protection?

2. National Security: the production of some goods and services are essential to maintaining a country’s national security, which refers to the ability of the country to protect itself in times of conflict. It would, therefore, be unwise to be reliant on countries for the production of weapons systems as there is no guarantee that they will be able to provide them readily in times of conflict.
What is the protection of local jobs argument for supporting trade protection

3. Protection of local jobs: While trade liberalisation often comes with the reduction of prices, it does mean that local output is constrained, forcing firms to make workers redundant. As a result, unemployment is likely to increase.
What is the Anti-dumping and unfair competition argument for supporting trade protection

4. Anti-Dumping and unfair competition: Foreign firms that have been heavily and unfairly subsidized by their government can sell goods and services that local firms simply are unable to compete with, as prices exist below local costs of production. This leads them to leave the market.
What is the balance of payments argument for supporting trade protection?

5. Balance of Payments correction: This occurs when the outflow of money from a country is greater than the inflow of money, meaning that imports expenditure exceeds export revenue. This can lead to currency devaluation and put strain on a country’s current account.
What is the ELDCs and diversification argument for supporting trade protection?

6. ELDCs and Diversification: ELDCs rely heavily on the export of a few primary commodities leading to them becoming over-specialised in their production. Export dependency on these goods are unfavorable as they have high volatility and it is difficult to add value to primary commodities. (Barriers to economic development will have a better explanation)
What is the government revenue from tariffs argument for supporting trade protection?
7. Government Revenue from Tariffs: The opportunity cost of removing the tariff and losing out on that tax revenue from which governments can subside merit goods and provide public goods.
What is the misallocation of reasources argument for free-trade?

1. Misallocation of Resources: Trade de-liberalisation can lead to the misallocation of resources by protecting inefficient industries. Instead of allowing resources to flow to the most competitive sectors, protectionist measures can keep unproductive firms afloat, hindering overall economic growth.
What is the retaliation argument for supporting free-trade?

1. Retaliation: Countries that face trade barriers may respond with their own protectionist measures, leading to a trade war. This can escalate tensions and result in broader economic consequences, negatively affecting global trade relationships.
What is the higher price & lower choice argument for supporting free-trade?

1. Higher Prices & Less Choice: Trade barriers often result in higher prices for consumers, as protected industries may lack the incentive to lower costs. Additionally, consumers face fewer choices when foreign goods are restricted, limiting access to diverse products.
What is the lack of incentive argument for free-trade

1. Lack of Incentive to be Competitive, Efficient, and to Innovate: When local industries are shielded from foreign competition, there may be less motivation to improve efficiency or innovate. This can lead to stagnation in industries that could otherwise thrive in a competitive environment, ultimately harming economic progress.
What is economic integration?
Economic Integration refers to the cooperation and coordination between countries’ trade policies to collectively reduce trade barriers.
What is a preferential trade agreement (PTA) ?

A Preferential Trade Agreement (henceforth PTA), is an agreement between 2 or more countries to lower trade barriers between them on particular products in trade between them. For PTAs, trade barriers may remain on the rest of the products, and on imports from countries not part of the agreement. The result is that members of the trade agreement have easier access to specific goods part of the agreement.
What are trading blocs?
Trading Blocs: Trading blocs are a group of countries that have decided to reduce tariffs and other barriers for the purpose of encouraging freer trade.
What is a Free Trade Area, give an example of one, and give a disadvantage of them?

Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) : These refer to the situation where a group of countries decide to reduce trade barriers, but keep their own independent trade policies towards foreign countries. An example would be NAFTA (North American Free Trade Agreement) between Canada, the USA, and Mexico. 

One very big problem with this type of trade architecture is that countries can still indirectly sell their goods and services to countries that prevent it. This is done by trading to a country in the FTA with less barriers to foreign trade, and then the country then sells to the other country in the FTA.
What is a customs union, give an example, and give a disadvantage

Customs Unions : These are a type of trading bloc that are more liberalised than FTAs. They fulfil the requirements of an FTA, which entails the reduction of trade restrictions between member countries, while also adopting the same common policies towards countries not part of the agreement. 

Each country is no longer able to determine its own policy towards other countries, leading to a loss in sovereignty. But since all countries have to adopt the same policies it entails a higher degree of economic integration.
What is a common market, give an example, and give a disadvantage

Common markets: This is the 3rd and final type of trading blocs. It fulfils all the requirements of a customs union, meaning that all countries have limited trade barriers between them for certain goods while also adopting the same common policy to external countries. In addition to this, common markets eliminate all restrictions on the movement of factors of production FOPs between them.

Labour and capital are free to move within these countries and find employment opportunities. Not only does this mean lower price, better quality, and greater choice, but it also means that FOPs are used better.

If, for example, one country has high unemployment but high demand for labour (shortage of labour) then workers from other countries can move there and find work.
What is trade creation argument for evaluating trading blocs?

• Trade Creation: As a result of economic integration and trade agreements, trading patterns inevitably change. This refers to the situation where higher cost imports from some countries are replaced with lower cost imports from countries in the same trade agreement.
What is the efficiency & economies of scale argument for supporting trading blocs?

• Economies of Scale & Efficiency: With the lowering of trade barriers between a trading bloc, firms are collectively likely to output more goods and services. In the long-run, as firms grow in size, this allows them to take advantage of economies of scale and achieve lower average costs. This also leads to more efficient production of goods and services, as inefficient firms are forced to close down (they are not saved by trade protection.)
What is the FOP argument for supporting trading blocs

• Better use of FOPs and better employment opportunities: Labour and capital are free to move within these countries and find employment opportunities. Not only does this mean lower price, better quality, and greater choice, but it also means that FOPs are used better.
What is the increased investment argument for supporting trading blocs?

• Increased investment: Larger markets create incentives for MNCs or local firms to set up production locally within the trading bloc to avoid tariffs if they sell outside. This leads to increased investment expenditure into the country.
What is the stronger bargaining power argument for supporting trading blocs?
• Stronger bargaining power: with other countries.
What is the trade diversion argument against trading blocs?

• Trade Diversion: In the same way trade can be created through trading blocs, trade can be also diverted away from trading blocs. This is because lower cost imports are replaced with higher cost imports from countries in the same trading bloc, as there is a tendency to favor them over foreign firms. Also if the same common policy is adopted, foreign options could become more expensive
What is the soveriegnty argument against trading bloc?

• Loss of Sovereignty: Economic integration itself entails a loss in sovereignty. This is because each country no longer acts as a sovereign individual, instead having to comply with the demands of the bloc as a whole. This includes foreign policy and political stances in an effort to reduce friction.
What is the unequalness arguement against trading blocs?

• Unequal gains and possible losses: Countries forming a trade bloc are unlikely to benefit equally as a result of the trade bloc, and this creates conflict between members. Some countries may even suffer a net loss as a result of the formation of a trading bloc.
What is a Monetary Union?
Monetary Union: A monetary union involves a far greater degree of economic integration than a common market, and it occurs when a country adopts the same central bank and the same currency
What is the exchange rate advantage of monetary unions?

1. A common currency eliminates the risk of exchange rate changes between member countries.
  2. Therefore, it reduces uncertainties for traders and investors, who might have needed to predict future exchange rates.
  3. Further, this stability encourages trade and investment within the union as:
    1. It removes the hassle of exchanging currencies, benefitting importers and exporters.
    2. This leads to easy trade and investments, which helps achieve a more efficient allocation of resources.
What is the price transparancy advantage of a monetary union

1. This is the ability for producers and consumers to be able to perform price comparisons in any member country without having to do calculations or conversions.
  2. Therefore, it allows economic decision-makers to observe price differences and price comparisons which is more accurate and faster to retrieve.
  3. This could lead to promoting competition and efficiency, which could cause lower prices for consumers.
What is the conversion advantage of monetary unions?

1. Both consumers and producers save money by not needing to exchange currencies and pay a fee to the bank or institution for the conversions.
  2. These savings can be significant and could lead to further trade and investments.
What is the inward investment advantage for Monetary Union?

1. The absence of exchange rate risks makes monetary unions more appealing for foreign direct investment (FDI).
  2. Therefore, with higher FDI, there will be higher economic growth and job creation.
What is the inflation advantage of a Monetary Union?

1. Unlike normal cases, member countries cannot depreciate the currency (since there isn't a domestic currency) if they have a high rate of inflation, hence a current account deficit.
  2. Thus, all member countries are committed to keeping a low rate of inflation.
  3. This provides a multitude of important benefits:
    1. Low rates of interest
    2. Higher levels of investments
    3. Higher production output
What is a the monetary policy disadvantage of a monetary union?

1. Each member country cannot change the level of economic activity, in particular the interest rate by implementing its own monetary policies.
  2. This is because monetary policies are set by the central common bank.
  3. Therefore, each member country will have difficulties to correct its economic challenges such as low/high inflation, unemployment, etc.
What is the loss of exchange rate disadvantage of a Monetary Union?

1. The member country can no longer depreciate the currency to correct a trade deficit as it does not have a national currency anymore.
  2. Further, it cannot solve high risks of inflation using currencies.
  3. This lack of flexibility or options can make it harder to respond to economic shocks as it has to rely on fiscal policies to correct any imbalances.
What is the loss of sovereignty disadvanage of Monetary Unions?

1. Mentioned previously, there are no national central banks for each member country and national governments are unable to implement policies freely due to convergence requirements.
  2. Rather, the central bank and an independent body implements and oversees policies. This is a severe loss of sovereignty.
What is the convergence disadvantage of a monetary union?

1. Even though each member country still has abilities to implement its own fiscal policies, there are convergence requirements that the countries need to adhere to.
  2. Factors such as setting limits on total public debt budget deficits, etc limit the extent or level of fiscal policies member countries can implement.
  3. Convergence requirements is often debated as:
    1. Many member countries view it as an advantage since it enforces fiscal discipline.
    2. Whilst, many believe it acts as a restriction of the authority or sovereignty of a country's government
What is the WTO (World Trade Organisation) and what is it responsible for doing?

The World Trade Organisation: The WTO is an organisation responsible for liberalization and the freeing up trade between countries. It has the following functions:
  1. Handling trade disputes ad finds ways to resolve disputes when they occur between members of the WTO
  2. Administers trade agreements. The WTO helps in the implementation and creation of trade agreements.
  3. Monitors international trade policies. The WTO carries reviews to make sure all member nations are remaining compliant with their trade regulations.
Name the critisisms of the WTO

• The WTO’s members have very unequal bargaining power within the organisation itself. While each country has one vote in the WTO, people argue it is still undemocratic because economically, if less powerful companies do not give into the agendas set by powerful companies, they risk retaliation. Additionally, the formation of coalitions where strong countries group up.
  • Difficulty reaching agreements with primary commodities.The WTO has been unable to reach an agreement on the protection of primary commodities. Developed countries have long been protecting their farmers with export and production subsidies, causing a lot of damage to developing countries.
What is the foreign exchange?

Foreign exchange is the exchange of currency for other currencies by firms, governments, and individuals. This typically happens on a ForEx market and entities ‘sell’ or supply their currency to ‘buy’ or demand another currency.
What is the floating exchange rate system and draw a relavent diagram.

The Floating Exchange Rate System: In a floating exchange rate system, the exchange rate between currencies are determined by the forces of demand and supply. The government plays no part in determining the exchange rate.
What is currency appreciation?

Appreciation is the situation where one currency increases in value relative to another currency; one unit of said currency can be exchanged for more units of another currency. This is due to an increase in demand for the currency or reduction in supply.
What is import substituion
• Import substitution: this is when a country begins to manufacture goods and services domestically to promote its domestic industry and decrease its reliance on imported goods.
What is export promotion?
Aims to increase the level of exports through subsidies or facilitating international trade fairs at which local firms can connect with international buyers.
Name the factors affecting exports in currency demand (3)

• Foreign demand of goods and services: This increases export revenue, leading to local currency to be more demanded by foreign countries. Hence, currency appreciates.
  • Relative rates of inflation: If the local rate of inflation is higher than the foreign one, exports become more expensive. This causes a reduction in demand for local currency, causing currency depreciation.
  • Relative Growth rates: If Kenya’s trading partners experience higher economic growth, they are more likely to demand goods and services from Kenya. Thus demand for Kenya’s currency increases, causing currency appreciation.
Factors affecting investment in currency appreciation in demand (2)

• Relative Interest rates: If the interest rate in one country is higher than another, it becomes a more favorable place for investment. This is because investors can earn a higher return, leading to currency appreciation due to increases in demand.
  • FDI and portfolio investment: Both of these increase demand for the currency, leading to currency appreciation.
Other factors affecting currency appreciation in demand

• Flow of remittances: Increase in remittance (transfer of money from a foreign country to another country, usually by workers wanting to send money back to their families) payments cause local currency demand to increase, leading to currency appreciation.
  • Speculation: If someone expects a currency’s value to increase, they will buy that currency, increasing its demand. This actually causes it to increase itself. 
  • Central Bank Intervention: If the central bank wants currency appreciation, it will buy domestic currency with its existing foreign reserves. This causes demand for the currency to increase, and the currency to therefore appreciate.
Factors affecting import expenditure affecting currency supply (3)

• Domestic demand for imports: Changes in the demand for foreign imports lead to changes in supply of local currency. If imports increase, so does supply, thereby causing currency depreciation. 
  • Relative inflation rates: If inflation is higher in one country than another, locally produced goods become more expensive. As a result it relies on imports, supplying currency and causing currency depreciation. This reinforces the effect from the export section.
  • Relative Growth rates: If Kenya’s trading partners experience higher economic growth than Kenya, Kenya’s imports will decrease, causing supply of currency to decrease and currency to appreciate.
Factors affecting currency supply in investment

• Relative Interest rates: If the interest rate in one country is higher than another, it becomes a more favorable place for investment. As a result, if this is the home country, investment inwards increases. Thus, less investment is done outwards, decreasing supply and causing currency appreciation. 
  • Outward FDI and portfolio investment: Investment in FDI and portfolio investment by a home country causes supply of currency to increase, causing currency depreciation.
Other factors affecting currency supply (3)

• Speculation that another country's currency will increase: If another country’s currency is expected to increase, local currency is supplied for that currency. This increases supply for currency, causing currency depreciation.
  • Outward remittances: More remittances out means more supply of currency outwards, causing more supply. Hence, supply increases and currency depreciation.
  • Central bank intervention: If the central bank wants to cause currency depreciation, it sells its local reserves of currency (by buying foreign reserves) and this causes more supply and therefore currency depreciation.
What characterises poor people?

- People who spend most of their income on necessities. 
- People with very low levels of physical and human capital
Draw and explain a fully labelled poverty cycle diagram

Poverty is characterised by very low income relative to others, leading to low savings. With low savings, people in poverty are unavke to invest in proper nuitrition and education, limiting their human capital. Moreover, they aren't able to invest in tools and equipment leading to low physical capital. Additionally, they cannot invest in things like fertilizer to improve natural capital. This means that they are unproductive and therefore earn very little additional income, leading to low relative income. Thus the cycle repeats.
Explain why income inequality is a barrier to economic growth

This can be explained by considering the effects of the poverty cycle: low relative income means that citizens are unable to invest in human capital and physical capital, limiting their productivity and contribution to the economy. Additionally, people in poverty are often malnourished and are not in the best physical shape, making them unemployable and often sick. This means that governments will have to pay more in healthcare and unemployment fees, limiting the amount it can support buregoning firms with.
What is infrastructure?

Infrastructure is a type of physical capital, meaning it comes from investment expenditure, typically by the government. It refers to all goods or services tjat are necassary for a functioning economy: telecommunications, transport, roads, power, irrigation, drainage, and more. Most types of infrastructure are public goods with positive externalities of consumption.
Why is limited infrastructure a barrier to economic growth?

Firms and citizens benefit heavlity from infrastructure to carry out economic actitivies. If infrastructure did not exists, average costs for firms would greatly increase and citizens would have to expend more to live. This means that firms would be less productive and less competative, and workers would have to demand higher wages (also making firms less competative as it increases their costs.)
Why is limited access to appropriate technology a barrier to economic growth?

Technology improves the productivity of physical capital, leading to greater output. But with this, it is important that developing countries consider the apporpriateness of certain technologies. Developing countries are typically characterised by having a large amount of labour, most of which are underemployed or unemploymed. In contrast, it is difficult for developing countries to benefit from advanced technology, because it becomes too costy to produce, use, and maintain. Therefore, developing countries benefit from labour intensive technologies - ones that take advantage of their large labour force and increases employment and productivity. This also helps reduce poverty and dependance on importing technology.

The problem is that most R&D comes from developed countries, and they typically make advancements in the capital-intensive section of technology. This is because capital intensive tech is more suited for their needs. Developing countries hardly invest in R&D, making it difficult to aquire appropriate tech for them.
Explain why limited access to international markets is a barrier to economic growth

Tariff barriers:
- In an attempt to help local farmers, many countries have very high tariffs on agricultural goods and servcies. Since developing countries typically specialise in the production of primary goods, including argiculture, it makes it difficult for them to compete with domestic firms in other countries. This is because the tariff serves to icnrease the world price, making exports to other countries less competative. With less competative exports, export revenue decreases leading to less economic growth as net exports are a component of real gdp. 

- Tariff escalation for manufactured goods are also typically much higher than on primary commodities. This disincentivisises firms to perform vertical diversification wherein they use their primary commodities to make manufactured goods. As a result, the structural changes which permit industrialisation in the economy are prevented, and the economy remains in primarily in the primary sector. 

Agricultural subsidies:
- In international trade, one of the most problematic issues is when rich countries excessively subsidise the agricultural industry, under the veil of protecting farmers' income. Yet the majority of the subsitdes are enjoyed by large farmers, already benefiting from economies of scale. 

Administative barriers:
- Rejection of imports due to not meeting health, saftey, and quality 'standards.' Limits export revenue.
Why is capital flight a barrier to economic growth?

Capital flight is the large scale transfer of financial capital out of a country, usually due to high degrees of percieved risk and uncertainty in the country's future economic health. Residents of the country are fearful of holding assets in the country, perhaps due to political instabllity, corruption and fear that their assets will be confiscated by the state. 

This is a problem as it exterts a downward pressure on the currency due to increased supply, leading to curreny depreciation. Greater depreciation means that asset prices decrease relative to other currencies, thereby making asset-holders fearful. This in turn, causes greater captial flight leading to even greater currency depreciation. In the end, the currency spirals downward 

This also worsens external debt, making it harder to pay of principal and interest payments.
Why is a indebtedness a barrier to economic growth?

- Debt servcing means that the government has fewer reasoruces to invest in social services, infrastructure, etc. 
- Poor credit rating makes it increasingly difficult for governments to borrow to fuel economic growth
- Taxes may need to increase, whihc is deflationery for the economy
- Income inequality as debt is owned by wealther individuals
- Lower FDI due to economic uncertainty
- Debt trap where the government keeps borrowing to repay old debt.
Why is ineffective taxation a social barrier to economic growth?

Governements need tax revenue to provide infrastrcure, invest in human capital, and undertake in other activities to increase economic growth. Bad tax structures can lead to less tax revenue, and therefore, less economic growth. Developing countries often have:

- corrupt tax systems; bribery to not pay tax.
- regressive/not pregressive enough taxt systems
- high dependance on tax for government revenue.
-inefficiencies in tax collection, invloving complex legislation and beauracratic procedures. This wastes reasources and creates ways people can evade tax. 
- Tax exemptions for wealth firms and people due to political connections. 
- Low property taxes. Not taxing the wealthier group of people who are holders of property. 

Negative effects on reasource allocation:
- capital goods are often exempt from taxes, leading to capital intensive production methods (bad for developing economies)
- Tax advantages enjoyed by old wealthy firms and medium sized firms face most of the tax burden.
Why is limited banking a barrier to economic development?

- Greater incentive for people to save, as there is a return on their saving via the bank through an interest rate. Leading to greater quality of life and condifence in the economy as people are more financially secure. 
- Provide firms with credit to expand their productive facillities, leading to greater investment-driven economic growth through higher output. 
- Credit to advance human capital and increase employment and productivity. More skilled labour form college degrees and more productivity.
- Poverty alleviation, as saved income will grow. Also allows them to buy necessities on credit and invest in physical and human capital.

Despite this, developing countries do not take advantage of the advantages of credit. Banks are typically more willing to lend to large MNCs as their earnings from interest payments are substainial and they are more trustworthy than smaller clients (they typically have collateral and good credit ratings.) 

As a result, people rely on the informal economy in 'loan sharks' to get money, who charge criminally high interest rates.
Why is lack of property and land rights a barrier to economic growth?

Property rights refer to the legislation that governs how property can be owned, used, and transfered in an economy. 

Risk in this needs to be minimised, as firms are reluctant to expand into making a new factory if they aren't sure that their property won't be confiscated or if the property isn't legally secured in their name. 

Investment and access to credit: INvestment expenditure is less risky if people property rights are not secure. There less access to credit as people cannot put their property up as collateral to take loans from banks. In the abscence of a legal title, banks may offer higher interest rates as they deem the transcation more risky. 

Critisisms: 

Also the problem of land-grabs
Why is gender inequality a barrier to economic development?

Gender inequalities in labour market:
Lower levels of skills and education make women less employable in comparison to men. Even if women do have the same skills as men, discrimination prevents them from securing a job. This makes women seek the informal economy to find work, leading to less skilled work, less pay, and exploitation. 
Women also have very low access to credit due to discrimination and wealth gaps. This is because they often don't have collateral to offer up to secure loans, leading to higher interest rates.
Why is corruption a barrier to economic growth?

Corruption is the abuse of public office for private gain at the expense of others. 

- Corruption can be thought of as a tax to obtain goods and services, making provate investments more costly, reducing the opportunities for investment-driven economic growth. 
- Corruption is also regressive like most taxes, as for payments to obtain basic services (bribes to teachers and health workers,) lower income households have to pay a greater portion of their income to have the same beenfits as higher income households. This creates a even more unequitable distriubtion of income, which stunts economic growth as people get trapped in poverty traps. 
- Corruption taken from tax revenue reduces the amount governments can expend on providing infrastructure and subsisiding education to increase human capital and health. 
- Causes a misallocation of reasources, as governments pursue uneeconomic projects as opposed to other projects that are actually needed in the economy leading to poor infrastructure. 
- Damages reputation of the country, causing less FDI and capital flight as people are unsure of the country's future.
Why is unequal political power and status a barrier to economic growth?

All societies have some level of social stratification, in which the population are organised in strata in terms of their wealth and status. A caste system, or a predispotioned lower class for some, harms economic growth as it does not reward those who contribute to the eocnomy.
What is Foreign Direct Investment?
Foreign Direct Investment is investment expenditure by multi-national coorperations from another country in the productive activities of a host country, of which they own at least 10% of the firm.
What are MNCs
Multinational companies are typically large businesses that have business operations in multiple countries
Give the Advantages and Disadvantages of FDI

Advantages
 1. MNCs can cause technology transfer to host countries. This can improve their physical capital, leading to greater productity and efficiencies in the host country's output. Also, MNCs engage in training programs which can improve the human capital of citizens, leading to better skills and more productivity. 
2. MNCs can help increase domestic employment, leading to lower unemployment in the industry. This alleviates poverty, as citizens can have savings to invest in education and physical capital to grow their incomes and break out of poverty. 
3. Through FDI investment expenditure into the country increases, causing investment-driven economic growth. MNCs can also be taxed by the government, and the tax revenue can be used to build infrastructure 
4. FDI flowing in as credits into the financial account can help offset any imbalance in international trade in the currenct account from having too many imports. Additionaly, since the activities of MNCs are usually export-oriented, they can also improve export revenue. 
5. MNCs can improve the local industry, as they rely on domestically produced factor inputs. This helps local firms grow and expand, eventually benefiting from economies of scale, making their average costs lower and benefiting international trade. 
Disadvantages:
1. Through repatriated profits, MNCs exert a downward pressure on the exchange rate, thereby causing exchange rate depreciation. This makes local assets decrease in price, risking capital flight. 
2. Environmental degredation. This is because MNCs typically pursue production with complete disregard for the environement to reduce costs, and because environmental laws are typically not very strong in developing countries. This impacts green GDP and sustainable development, compromising the future of the country. 
3. MNCs may import inapporpriate technology, which is a barrier to economic growth in developing countries. For example, if MNCs rely on capital intensive technologies as opposed to labour intensive technologies, workers can become structurally unemployed, leading to higher unemployment. 
4. MNCs may exert political pressure on labour laws, leading to countries to pursue economic policy in their own interest as opposed to improving economic growth and standards of living. 
5. Promote inapporpriate consumption patterns. MNCs that sell de-merit goods such as junk food could lead to greater external costs as consumers are now exposed to them at a cheap price.
What is foreign aid

Foreign aid is the transfer of funds from countries into developing countries with the intention of bringing improvements in their social, economic, and political conditions.
In order to qualify as aid, it must be concessional, meaninf better than what the free-market offers (e.g lower interest rate loan)
It must also be non-commerical, meaning that the aid-givers are not concerned with making a profit.
What is humanitarian aid?
Humanitarian aid is a type of aid given to countries stricken by natural disasters or violent conflicts in an effort to save lives and ensure basic necessities.
What is developmental aid?
Aid given to countries to achieve economic growth and development objectives. It typically involves the financing of several projects including hospitals, energy, and schools.
What is Official Development Assistance (ODA)
This is government aid from developed countries given to promote the economic, social and political well-being of developing countries.
What is private aid (NGOs) ?
This is aid given directly to NGOs, which are private firms that pursue the relief of suffering and the interests of the poor.
Give the advantages and disadvantages of foreign aid

Arguments in favour of Aid:
1. Aid and the poverty cycle: If the government lacks tax reveunes to intervene by increasing investment expenditure by investing in human capital and physical capital, it needs to rely on aid to lift people from the poverty cycle. Lifting people from the poverty cycle can make people and the economy more productive.
2. Aid and the debt trap: Countries that are heavily indebted and have fallen victim to the debt trap can use aid to allievate debt. Now, tax revenues can go to funding infrastructure and other things.
3. Improved income distribution. Bad income distribution is a barrier to economic growth.

Factors that limit aid:
1. Tied aid (where recipients of aid are forced to spend all or a large portion of the aid on the sender's goods and services.)
  • This means that import expenditure increases as they are forced to by the sender's products as a opposed to cheaper alternatives
  • purchasing of inappropriate, capital-intensive technologies
2. Conditional aid (Most donors of the ODA impose stipulations that need to be met if they were to give aid. This often refers to achieving more market orientation, but sometimes donors are ignorant into the real problems associated in the country. Thus they may impose counterproductive policies that the country needs to adopt.)
3. Uncoordinated donors can give rise to many inefficiencies
4. Aid may substitute government efforts to increase tax revenue rather than supplement.
What is multilateral development assistance?
This involves lending money to developing countries on non-concessional terms, meaning that at interest rates and repayment periods determined by the market.
What is the World Bank?
The World Bank is a development assistance organisation focusing on extending long-term loans to developing countries with the purpose of promoting economic growth and structural change.
What two parts make up the World Bank?

1. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) that lends out loans at non-concessional terms to middle income developing countries. 
2. The Internation Development Acossiation (IDA) that lends out loans at concessional terms to low income developing countries.
Evaluating the World Bank

1. Social and enviornmental concerns. In the early years, the World Bank was ignorant as to the effects of the society, as it often aided projects that displaced indigenuos people. Moreover, it lacked concern for the environment. However, in recent years, it has become more aware as to the effects it has on the enviornemnt and society. 
2. The World Bank is dominated by wealthier countries as voting power increases with the amount donated. 
3. Excessive interference in other countries domestic affaires
4. Conditional lending
What is the International Monetary Fund?

The IMF is a multilateral financial institution established jointly with the World Bank. Its purpose is to oversee the global financial system, manage macroeconomic policies, and stabilise exchange rates.
What is the role of the IMF?

The IMF comes as a package where a country must adopt the following to take advantage of loans. These are called stabilisation policies:
1. Contractionery monetary policy/Contractionery Fiscal Policy/Currency Devaluation/Cuts in real-wages. This raises interest rates, leading to reduced consumption in the economy. As a result economic growth declines, demonstrated as AD decreases. This causes demand for imports to reduce, decreasing import expenditure.
Evaluate the IMF?
What is Demand
The amount of goods and services that individuals are willing to buy at different prices in a time level (ceteris paribus).
What are the non-price determinants of demand

• Income
  • Tastes and preferences
  • Future price expectations
  • Price of related goods
  • Number of consumers
Law of Demand.
The quantity demanded of a product will fall if price rises, and vice versa, ceteris paribus.
What are the assumptions underlying the Law of Demand

1. The income effect (real income is proportional to consumption)
  2. The substitution effect (price of substitute goods)
  3. The law of diminishing marginal utility (the more you have of something, the less you want it)
The Demand Curve

A downwards-sloping demand line labelled D
"Price" in a currency on the y-axis
"Quantity Demanded" in a relevant unit on the x-axis
Arrows on both axes
Individual vs. Market Demand
Market Demand is the aggregate of all Individual Demand on a product.
What is Supply
Quantity of goods and services that firms are willing and able to provide/sell in a time period.
Law of Supply
There is a positive relationship between quantity supplied and price, ceteris paribus.
Assumptions underlying the Law of Supply

1. Increasing marginal costs (likewise to above)
  2. Increasing diminishing marginal returns (more factor of production results in lower returns)
